list_definition.definition: (the right to show) one’s wish or opinion, eg in a ballot or by raising a hand etc, especially at an election or in a debate

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: In Britain, the vote was given to women over twenty-one in 1928
Nowadays everyone over eighteen has a vote
A vote was taken to decide the matter.

list_definition.definition: to cast or record one’s vote

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She voted for the Conservative candidate
I shall vote against the restoration of capital punishment.

list_definition.definition: to allow, by a vote, the provision of (something) eg to someone, for a purpose etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: They were voted $5,000 to help them in their research.

list_ex_of_english: Members of authorizing committees have delegated to members of appropriations committees the power (subject to floor votes) to limit spending.
